channel.title: My first java applet game[Updated]
channel.description:
A game I've made in java: [url=http://pythedev.awardspace.info/invaders.html]http://pythedev.awardspace.info/invaders.html[/url] Now It has: * 10 levels * Enemies have shields * Faster bullets * Enemies shoot slow and fast bullets(depends of their type) * Defensive blocks * Better smoke * Fixed "All shooting together" bug
Any cool ideas for a new game?

item.title: My first java applet game[Updated]
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

No point re-inventing the wheel unless you specifically want to learn how to invent that wheel, or you are actually trying to improve on it, hence perhaps writing another library, which in this instance wouldn’t be the goal. Just use GOOD, SOLID libs.

Read full topic

item.title: My first java applet game[Updated]
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:41, topic:311553”][quote author=ollie123 link=topic=408001.msg3015812#msg3015812 date=1257186632]

I agree with Speljohan, no point in using a crappy lib or making your own when there’s a good one available.
[/quote] Exactly; why re-invent the wheel?

To learn how it works.[/quote]

Whilst I agree with you, why not just thoroughly examine the source code from an open-source library like Slick2D? Besides, looking at code from a library that makes use of all of Java’s features e.g. hardware-accelerated images would surely encourage better programming practices, wouldn’t it?

Read full topic

item.title: My first java applet game[Updated]
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“West7man, post:36, topic:311553”]I’ve used similar ways in my game project to store game data…
I think I’m changing back to my old style(nanoseconds are stupid):

[CODE]package system;

import java.applet.Applet;
import java.awt.Color;
import java.awt.Graphics;
import java.awt.Image;

import system.log;

public class run extends Applet implements Runnable{

private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;

int Width     = 500;
int Height    = 500;
int LogLength = 50;
int Thread_FPS = 40;
double Thread_LoopTime, Thread_WaitTime, Thread_Ms;
String AppletName  = "SampleApp";
String VersionInfo = "0.1 alpha";
Graphics BufferGraphics;
Image BufferImage;
Thread MainThread;

log Log = new log(LogLength);

public void init() {
	Thread_Ms = 1000/Thread_FPS;
	Log.Add(AppletName+" version "+VersionInfo+".");
	BufferImage = createImage(Width, Height);
	BufferGraphics = BufferImage.getGraphics();
}

public void start() {
	if(MainThread == null){
		MainThread = new Thread(this);
		MainThread.start();
	}
}

public void run() {
	while(MainThread != null) {
		try{
			if(System.currentTimeMillis() - Thread_LoopTime < Thread_Ms) {
				Thread_WaitTime = Thread_Ms - (System.currentTimeMillis() - Thread_LoopTime);
			}
			Thread.sleep((int)Thread_Ms);
			Thread_LoopTime = System.currentTimeMillis();
			repaint();
		} catch(InterruptedException e) {
				Log.Add("Error while running main thread.");
		}
	}
}

public void paint(Graphics graphics) {
	BufferGraphics.setColor(Color.white);
	BufferGraphics.fillRect(0, 0, Width, Height);
	BufferGraphics.setColor(Color.black);
	BufferGraphics.drawString("Hello World!", 20, 30);
	BufferGraphics.drawString(AppletName+" version "+VersionInfo+".", 20, 50);
	BufferGraphics.drawString("Time: "+Thread_Ms+" Waiting:"+Thread_WaitTime, 100, 100);
	graphics.drawImage(BufferImage,0,0,this);
}

public void update(Graphics graphics) { 
     paint(graphics); 
}

public void stop() {
     if(MainThread != null && MainThread.isAlive()) MainThread.stop();
     MainThread = null;
     Log.Add("Program stopped.");
}

}[/CODE][/quote]I’d still suggest using a pre-made game framework that utilizes your graphics card, it’s better in the long run

Read full topic

item.title: My first java applet game[Updated]
item.dc:creator: @West7man West7man
item.description:
@West7man wrote:

I’ve used similar ways in my game project to store game data…
I think I’m changing back to my old style(nanoseconds are stupid):

[CODE]package system;

import java.applet.Applet;
import java.awt.Color;
import java.awt.Graphics;
import java.awt.Image;

import system.log;

public class run extends Applet implements Runnable{

private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;

int Width     = 500;
int Height    = 500;
int LogLength = 50;
int Thread_FPS = 40;
double Thread_LoopTime, Thread_WaitTime, Thread_Ms;
String AppletName  = "SampleApp";
String VersionInfo = "0.1 alpha";
Graphics BufferGraphics;
Image BufferImage;
Thread MainThread;

log Log = new log(LogLength);

public void init() {
	Thread_Ms = 1000/Thread_FPS;
	Log.Add(AppletName+" version "+VersionInfo+".");
	BufferImage = createImage(Width, Height);
	BufferGraphics = BufferImage.getGraphics();
}

public void start() {
	if(MainThread == null){
		MainThread = new Thread(this);
		MainThread.start();
	}
}

public void run() {
	while(MainThread != null) {
		try{
			if(System.currentTimeMillis() - Thread_LoopTime < Thread_Ms) {
				Thread_WaitTime = Thread_Ms - (System.currentTimeMillis() - Thread_LoopTime);
			}
			Thread.sleep((int)Thread_Ms);
			Thread_LoopTime = System.currentTimeMillis();
			repaint();
		} catch(InterruptedException e) {
				Log.Add("Error while running main thread.");
		}
	}
}

public void paint(Graphics graphics) {
	BufferGraphics.setColor(Color.white);
	BufferGraphics.fillRect(0, 0, Width, Height);
	BufferGraphics.setColor(Color.black);
	BufferGraphics.drawString("Hello World!", 20, 30);
	BufferGraphics.drawString(AppletName+" version "+VersionInfo+".", 20, 50);
	BufferGraphics.drawString("Time: "+Thread_Ms+" Waiting:"+Thread_WaitTime, 100, 100);
	graphics.drawImage(BufferImage,0,0,this);
}

public void update(Graphics graphics) { 
     paint(graphics); 
}

public void stop() {
     if(MainThread != null && MainThread.isAlive()) MainThread.stop();
     MainThread = null;
     Log.Add("Program stopped.");
}

}[/CODE]

Yes, slick is easy but I still want to do it in the hard way…

Read full topic

item.title: My first java applet game[Updated]
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“West7man, post:34, topic:311553”]I’ve created a “base project” for 2d applet games in java… But I dont know if it is stable enough…

public void run(){ double NeutralTime = 1000000000/SystemFPS; double TimeTaken; while(MainThread != null){ try{ TimeTaken = System.nanoTime()-threadNanos; if(TimeTaken < NeutralTime){ realFPS = SystemFPS; if((int)(NeutralTime - TimeTaken) < 1000000){ Thread.sleep(0,(int)(NeutralTime - TimeTaken)); }else{ Thread.sleep((int)((NeutralTime - TimeTaken)/1000000)); } }else{ realFPS = (int)(1000000000/TimeTaken); } threadNanos = System.nanoTime(); repaint(); //TODO: code goes here }catch(InterruptedException e){ Log.Add("Error while running main thread."); } } }
Yeah I’ve made it with the sharpness of nanoseconds…
Gonna leech somewhere better code :P[/quote]This is how a project could look with slick2d:

Main.java:

[code]public class Main extends StateBasedGame {

public Main(String name) {
    super(name);
    this.enterState(1);
}

public static void main(String[] args) throws SlickException {
    AppGameContainer app = new AppGameContainer(new Main("Game Name"));
    app.setDisplayMode(800, 600, false);
    app.setTargetFrameRate(60);
    app.setVSync(true);
    app.start();
    
}

public void initStatesList(GameContainer gameContainer) throws SlickException {
    loadResources();
    this.getState(1).init(gameContainer, this);
}

public void loadResources() throws SlickException {
    ResourceList.addImage("Ball", new Image("./res/Ball.PNG"));
}

}
[/code]

GameState.java:

[code]public class GameState extends BasicGameState {

public int getID() {
    return 1;
}

public void init(GameContainer gameContainer, StateBasedGame stateBasedGame) throws SlickException {
       //Call when initializing this state
}

public void render(GameContainer gameContainer, StateBasedGame stateBasedGame, Graphics graphics) throws SlickException {
    //Draw all graphics here
    graphics.drawImage(ResourceList.getImage("Ball"), 50, 70, Color.red);
}

public void update(GameContainer gameContainer, StateBasedGame stateBasedGame, int i) throws SlickException {
         //Do all logics here
}

}
[/code]

As you can see it’s very easy to use

Read full topic

item.title: My first java applet game[Updated]
item.dc:creator: @West7man West7man
item.description:
@West7man wrote:

I’ve created a “base project” for 2d applet games in java… But I dont know if it is stable enough(for slower machines it would probably lagg if the fps is set high)…

public void run(){ double NeutralTime = 1000000000/SystemFPS; double TimeTaken; while(MainThread != null){ try{ TimeTaken = System.nanoTime()-threadNanos; if(TimeTaken < NeutralTime){ realFPS = SystemFPS; if((int)(NeutralTime - TimeTaken) < 1000000){ Thread.sleep(0,(int)(NeutralTime - TimeTaken)); }else{ Thread.sleep((int)((NeutralTime - TimeTaken)/1000000)); } }else{ realFPS = (int)(1000000000/TimeTaken); } threadNanos = System.nanoTime(); repaint(); //TODO: code goes here }catch(InterruptedException e){ Log.Add("Error while running main thread."); } } }
Yeah I’ve made it with the sharpness of nanoseconds…
Gonna leech somewhere better code

Read full topic

item.title: My first java applet game[Updated]
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Kinda takes some serious effort and time to learn C++ (and a good book), so probably starting it through SDL (which is a particularly ugly C library) or even Irrlicht (which though much better it’s still too advanced for beginners) wasn’t a good idea.

If you wanna get started making 3D games easily, Python and C# are good choices IMHO. Both are easy. With Python you’ve libraries such as PyOgre available, and for C# you have Axiom / Mogre / XNA (Note that XNA is relatively low level). C# is not in your list so in case you don’t know, it’s very similar to Java but more modern and more powerful.

Read full topic

item.title: My first java applet game[Updated]
item.dc:creator: @West7man West7man
item.description:
@West7man wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:19, topic:311553”]Hey how are you adding levels so quicky?
It’s almost as if your using G-Java…[/quote]
No, It’s pure regular Java. I just made a very dynamic alien enemy class:
Alien(int type, int rowPosition, linePosition, Image alienImg){}
and of the type it depends if the alien is shielded, shooting etc…
That makes level making just very easy:
switch(level){
case 1:
Alien alien[20];
for(int i = 0; i < 10; i++) alien[i] = new Alien(1, 1, i, img_alienShooting);
for(int i = 10; i < 20; i++) alien[i] = new Alien(2, 2, i-10, img_alienShootingFast);
case 2:
Alien alien[18]
…and so on… (I’m tired it’s 2am so don’t repair me)

[quote=“abraham2119, post:20, topic:311553”]west7man, this is always a good idea:
pokemanz are kewl![/quote]
I’ve tried to create mmorpg-s since I was 15 using Blitz3d or 2d… Also I’ve tried to make a rs private server in c++. It’s just a hammer! I don’t want to try again… Because 95% I’ll fail.
Btw blitz basic was fun and easy. I learned how to program games so that they would be “compact” and how to create dynamic smart functions, mostly just for games…
But yeah I’ve used c++(visual) for a year. I’ve tried lots of stuff like libraries irrlicht and SDL. Now I hate c++. It’s just 'gay. Java is cool! and python too:P There are 3 languages that I’m going to use in the future: Java, PHP and python… oh and css + html + sql too!

btw I’m not a fan of pokjemonz or gigimonz… But I still like your idea… It would be kind of fun to put digimon, naruto and chris crocker under the same pot.

Read full topic
